entities.name: SIR SANDFORD FLEMING
entities.description: Canadian engineer who proposed the concept of dividing the world into 24 time zones, each representing a one-hour difference in mean solar time

entities.name: BRITISH RAILWAY COMPANIES
entities.description: Companies that adopted a single standard time for their schedules in 1847, known as Railway Time

entities.name: GREENWICH MERIDIAN
entities.description: The Prime Meridian located in London, chosen as the reference point for coordinating time across the globe

entities.name: INTERNATIONAL MERIDIAN CONFERENCE
entities.description: Conference held in Washington, D.C. in 1884 where it was agreed to adopt a system of standard time zones based on Greenwich Mean Time (GMT)

entities.name: UNITED STATES
entities.description: Country that divided itself into four time zones: Eastern, Central, Mountain, and Pacific

entities.name: DAYLIGHT SAVING TIME (DST)
entities.description: Practice of advancing clocks by one hour during the warmer months to extend daylight hours in the evening, first implemented during World War I

entities.name: GREENWICH MEAN TIME (GMT)
entities.description: Time standard used as the reference point for coordinating time across the globe, based on the time at the Greenwich Meridian

entities.name: WASHINGTON, D.C.
entities.description: City where the International Meridian Conference was held in 1884

entities.name: LONDON
entities.description: City where the Greenwich Meridian is located, serving as the reference point for global time zones

entities.name: EASTERN TIME ZONE
entities.description: One of the four time zones in the United States, covering the eastern part of the country

entities.name: CENTRAL TIME ZONE
entities.description: One of the four time zones in the United States, covering the central part of the country

entities.name: MOUNTAIN TIME ZONE
entities.description: One of the four time zones in the United States, covering the mountainous regions of the country

entities.name: PACIFIC TIME ZONE
entities.description: One of the four time zones in the United States, covering the western part of the country

relations: Sir Sandford Fleming's proposal for time zones was discussed and adopted at the International Meridian Conference
The British railway companies' adoption of Railway Time influenced the development of standard time zones, which were later formalized at the International Meridian Conference
The Greenwich Meridian was chosen as the Prime Meridian at the International Meridian Conference, serving as the reference point for all time zones
Greenwich Mean Time is based on the time at the Greenwich Meridian, which serves as the reference point for global time zones
The Greenwich Meridian is located in London, which serves as the reference point for global time zones
The United States adopted the time zone system agreed upon at the International Meridian Conference
While not directly related to the International Meridian Conference, the concept of time zones laid the groundwork for the later introduction of Daylight Saving Time
The International Meridian Conference was held in Washington, D.C. in 1884
The United States adopted the Eastern Time Zone as one of its four time zones
The United States adopted the Central Time Zone as one of its four time zones
The United States adopted the Mountain Time Zone as one of its four time zones
The United States adopted the Pacific Time Zone as one of its four time zones
The United States adopted time zones based on Greenwich Mean Time, which serves as the global reference point
Daylight Saving Time was first implemented during World War I as a way to conserve energy and make better use of natural daylight
The Eastern Time Zone is based on Greenwich Mean Time, which serves as the global reference point
The Central Time Zone is based on Greenwich Mean Time, which serves as the global reference point
The Mountain Time Zone is based on Greenwich Mean Time, which serves as the global reference point
The Pacific Time Zone is based on Greenwich Mean Time, which serves as the global reference point
